key_points: Utah doctor advises sticking with the same brand for COVID-19 booster shots, if possible.
Dr. Eddie Stenehjem of Intermountain Healthcare emphasizes matching booster shots to the original vaccine series.
CDC recommended booster shots for Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccines, following Pfizer's previous recommendation.
Utah has administered over 112,000 third doses of the Pfizer vaccine.
Utah's state epidemiologist, Dr. Leisha Nolen, highlights the importance of booster doses in preventing COVID-19 hospitalizations and deaths.
Healthcare workers in Utah have largely embraced booster shots without concern.
CDC's booster recommendations include older individuals, those with underlying conditions, and people in high-risk settings.
J&J booster is recommended for anyone 18 or over, at least two months after their initial shot.
Booster distribution in Utah follows an honor system without strict proof of eligibility.
CDC allows mixing vaccine brands for boosters to increase convenience and flexibility.
spokespersons: Dr. Eddie Stenehjem (Infectious diseases physician, Intermountain Healthcare)
Tom Hudachko (Spokesman, Utah Department of Health)
